did.abstract: Dean of the College of Engineering of the University of Michigan; correspondence, letter books, appraisals and reports, lectures, blueprints, newspaper clippings, photographs, and other materials concerning his activities as dean of the College of Engineering, engineer for the U.S.S. Yosemite in the Spanish American War, chairman of the Block Signal and Train Control Board, Democratic candidate for the U.S. Senate in 1924, and coordinator for the P.W.A. in Michigan in 1933-1935; also genealogical materials on the Cooley family.
did.physloc: Offsite storage; prior notification required for access.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection came primarily from Mortimer Cooley (donor no. 1755) and from the College of Engineering (donor no. 1884). A smaller portion of materials came from the Alumni Association (donor no. 1617).

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: item, folder title, box no., Mortimer E. Cooley Papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Mortimer E. Cooley was born in Canandaigua, New York on March 28, 1855. He graduated from the United States Naval Academy in 1878 as an engineer cadet. He advanced to the rank of assistant engineer in 1880, then in 1881, he was ordered to the University of Michigan as professor of steam engineering and iron shipbuilding. Cooley resigned from the navy in 1885 though he did serve a brief tour of volunteer naval duty during the Spanish-American War as chief engineer of the blockade ship, "Yosemite." In 1904 Cooley was made dean of the Department of Engineering and in 1913 he also selected as dean of the newly combined Departments of Engineering and Architecture (renamed in 1915 the College of Engineering and Architecture). Cooley retired as dean in 1928 but remained active at the University and in other capacities until his death in 1944.

Cooley made his mark as a expert in the area of public utilities, helping to develop standardized and meaningful methods for evaluating public utilities. In 1900, at the request of Governor Hazen S. Pingree, Cooley collaborated with U-M economist Henry Carter Adams in devising a viable and scientific method of determining railroad valuation for purposes of taxation. Because of the significance of this work, both Wisconsin and Minnesota looked to Cooley for help in developing their own systems of railroad evaluation. In addition, Cooley served as long-time advisor for the Interstate Commerce Commission and was its first consultant in its nationwide railroad appraisal program.

Cooley ran unsuccessfully for the United States Senate from Michigan in 1924. Among other issues, Cooley campaigned on the need for conservation and efficiency of resource use. Cooley believed that there should be more technically trained individuals in the Congress, including engineers and economist, not just attorneys and professional politicians. During the New Deal, Cooley was named state engineer for the Public Works Administration.

scopecontent.p: The Mortimer E. Cooley papers consists of correspondence, subject files, personal materials, and photographs detailing the professional career and activities of a distinguished engineering educator. The collection has been arranged into the following series: Correspondence; Topical Files; University of Michigan and College of Engineering materials; Genealogical and Miscellaneous; Arbitration, appraisal, and consultation files; Photographs; Naval Logs; and Testimonial and celebratory materials. Box 47 was eliminated during 2001 reprocessing.

scopecontent.p: Correspondence (44.3 linear ft.; 1873-1944) is the largest series in the collection and documents Cooley's extensive responsibilities as dean of the College of Engineering, as appraiser of railroads and other public utilities for Michigan and consultant, and as a leader in the field of engineering education.

Topical Files (1.7 linear ft.; 1880s-1940s) is an alphabetically arranged series of files on Cooley, his organizational affiliations, and his other projects and interests. Of note are those files from his work with the American Engineering Council (1919-1925); information about his unsuccessful campaign for the US Senate in 1924; and his service during the Spanish-American War.

scopecontent.p: University of Michigan and College of Engineering materials (1 linear ft.; 1905-1926) is a miscellanea of files largely on detailing the administration of the college and the particulars of engineering education. The researcher should note that the records of the College of Engineering during Cooley's deanship are also located at the Bentley Library.

did.unittitle: Engineering at the University of Michigan

odd.p: (includes 1883 stereocard of students outside engineering building)

did.unittitle: Greene. Charles E. Greene memorial tablet dedication

scopecontent.p: Genealogical and Miscellaneous (12 linear ft.; 1889-1935) consists mainly of materials accumulated by Cooley on the genealogy of his family. There are also some letterbooks and scrapbooks on his work with the PWA during the depression.

Notes on Water Wheels by M.E. Cooley

scopecontent.p: Arbitration, appraisal, and consultation files (6 linear ft.; 1893-1915) include information on Cooley's work with railroad and other public utilities appraisals. Cooley did work both for the state of Michigan and outside of the state. The researcher should note that Cooley's work in appraising Michigan's railroads for purposes of taxation is documented in the records of the Michigan Board of State Tax Commissioners also located at the Bentley Library.

scopecontent.p: The Photograph series (1.5 linear ft.) includes portraits; family portraits and homestead photos collected for his published Cooley family genealogy; University of Michigan photos, including buildings, classes and students, and laboratory facilities; and other buildings, individuals, and engineering projects.

scopecontent.p: Naval Logs (1890; 1898-1899; 1906; 5 oversize volumes) are from the U.S. Steamer Yosemite (and others) and are mainly from the period of the Spanish-American War.

scopecontent.p: Testimonial and celebratory materials (2 oversize volumes and 1 oversize folder) includes scrapbooks created for Cooley on birthdays and other celebrations. Included are letters of remembrance and congratulations and other memorabilia.
